Title: Python, PHP-style
Body:
I have used Python and PHP a lot, but just out of curiosity, **is there a version of Python that uses a similar paradigm to PHP for dynamic creation of html pages**, i.e. like this: for i in range(10): print '
Hello%i
' % i ?> ? Note: I'm **not** speaking about Django, Flask, Bottle, Twisted, etc. that don't use such syntax.

Title: invalid number (error token is "16##0x00a002")
Body:
i want to convert an hexadecimal value to decimal value perform some arithmetic operation and convert back to hexadecimal.
In an attempt to do so, i am facing the following error,

"myshell.sh: line 77: 16##0x00a002: invalid number (error token is "16##0x00a002")

The related line of code is 
"SUBVER3_1=$((16##$SUBVER3_1))"

Can someone let me know 
1) what this error is and how can i fix it.
2) How to perform Arithmetic operation on hexadecimal number in shell
MergedText:

Title: how to add route inside android mapfragment?
Body:
I am using google map in my app and i want to show route between two points.below are the latitudes and longitude.

    LatLng pune = new LatLng(18.6099, 73.8171);
    map.addMarker(new MarkerOptions().position(pune).title("Marker in pune"));
    map.moveCamera(CameraUpdateFactory.newLatLng(pune));
    mo.icon(BitmapDescriptorFactory.defaultMarker(BitmapDescriptorFactory.HUE_AZURE));

    LatLng mumbai = new LatLng(19.0829, 72.8831);
    map.addMarker(new MarkerOptions().position(mumbai).title("Marker in mumbai"));
    map.moveCamera(CameraUpdateFactory.newLatLng(mumbai));
    mo.icon(BitmapDescriptorFactory.defaultMarker(BitmapDescriptorFactory.HUE_AZURE));

Please help

Title: C++ : RAII idiom for classes with container members
MergedText:
<c++><c++11><containers><raii>, C++ : RAII idiom for classes with container members, I have the following questions about the class described in the code below:

    using namespace std;

    class Collector
    {
    public:
        Collector(const InfoPool& pool) { collect(pool) };

        collect(const InfoPool& pool)
        {
            for ( auto v : pool )
            {
              tuple<int,int> key = v.get_tuple();
              auto value = make_shared<Widget>(v.x(), v.y(), v.z());
              m_collection.insert(key, value);
            }
        }

    private:
        map< tuple<int,int>, shared_ptr<Widget> > m_collection;
    }

    int foo()
    {
        const InfoPool& pool = // ...
        auto c = std::make_shared<Widget>{ pool };
    }

1. I would like to know if it is RAII compliant. If not, how do I modify its implementation to make it so.

2. I wanted to confirm that the map Collector::m_container is stored on the free-store. Are both the tuple-keys and the Widgets both stored on the free-store?

3. Does foo leak memory?
ProcessedText: <c++><c++11><container><rain>, c++ : rain idiot class contain members, follow question class describe code below: use namespac st; class collector { public: collector(cost infopool& pool) { collect(pool) }; collect(cost infopool& pool) { ( auto v : pool ) { table<in,in> key = v.get_tuple(); auto value = make_shared<wide>(v.x(), v.y(), v.z()); collection.insert(key, value); } } private: map< table<in,in>, shared_ptr<wide> > collection; } in foo() { cost infopool& pool = // ... auto c = st::make_shared<wide>{ pool }; } 1. would like know rain complaint. not, modify implement make so. 2. want confirm map collector::contain store free-store. table-key wide store free-store? 3. foo leak memory?
